Let $\epsilon>0$. Is there a constant $C_\epsilon$ such that, for all large $n$, every graph on $n$ vertices with at least $n^{1+\epsilon}$ edges must contain a subgraph on at most $C_\epsilon$ vertices which is non-planar?



Erd\H{o}s \cite{Er71} writes it is 'not difficult to see' that $C_\epsilon\to \infty$ as $\epsilon\to 0$.

This was solved in the affirmative by Kostochka and Pyber \cite{KoPy88}, who proved that $G$ must contain a subdivision of $K_5$ (which is non-planar) with $O_\epsilon(1)$ many vertices.




References


[Er71] Erd\H{o}s, P., Some unsolved problems in graph theory and combinatorial analysis. Combinatorial Mathematics and its Applications (Proc.
Conf., Oxford, 1969) (1971), 97-109.

[KoPy88] Kostochka, A. and Pyber, L., Small topological complete subgraphs of ``dense'' graphs. Combinatorica (1988), 83--86.
